_description: Error resolutions for WiX build errors and MSIEXEC exit codes

resolutions.resolution: Remove duplicate BootstrapperApplication elements. Only one BootstrapperApplication can be specified per Bundle. If using both BootstrapperApplicationRef and a custom BA, choose one approach.

Move remote payloads to a separate container or make them embedded. BootstrapperApplication payloads must be embedded in the BA container for security. Use SourceFile attribute instead of DownloadUrl.
Ensure the WiX extension for the output type is installed. For .msi use 'wix extension add WixToolset.BootstrapperApplications.wixext' or similar. Check output file extension matches intended type.
Remove the Directory element defining the standard directory. Use StandardDirectory element to reference standard folders like ProgramFilesFolder, ProgramFiles64Folder, etc.
Replace DirectoryRef with StandardDirectory element. Change: <DirectoryRef Id='ProgramFilesFolder'> to <StandardDirectory Id='ProgramFilesFolder'>.
Remove the Version attribute from the Provides element in MSI packages. The version is automatically taken from the Package/@Version attribute.
Remove duplicate -bindpath variables from the command line. Each bind path variable should only be specified once.
Rename one of the duplicate identifiers or use access modifiers (internal, public, protected) to scope symbols appropriately. Each identifier must be unique within its scope.
This indicates the location of the duplicate symbol. Check both locations and decide which one to keep or rename.
Replace the placeholder regid value with your organization's actual reverse domain identifier (e.g., 'com.mycompany' becomes 'regid.YYYY-MM.com.mycompany').
Rename the bundle variable to start with a letter or underscore, followed by letters, digits, or underscores. Avoid reserved variable names and special characters.
Remove special characters from the provider key. Use only alphanumeric characters, periods, hyphens, and underscores. Provider keys must be valid identifier strings.
Change the Tag/@Name attribute to use only valid filename characters. Remove characters like: \ / : * ? " < > |
Remove layout-only payloads from containers. If the payload is for layout only, don't add it to a container. Use separate ExternalPayload for layout purposes.
Either add the payload to a PackageGroup, Chain, or BootstrapperApplication, or remove it if unused. All payloads must be referenced by a package or BA.
Remove the package from one of the containers. Each package can only belong to one container. Consider restructuring your containers.
Use the new WiX v4+ patch creation workflow. Create transforms manually or use 'wix msi diff' to generate patches instead of PatchCreation element.
Remove the payload reference from one container. Each payload can only be in one container. If needed in multiple places, create separate payload definitions.
Do not share payloads between BootstrapperApplication and regular packages. Create a separate payload definition for each usage context.
Update your code to use the replacement property or approach. Check WiX migration documentation for the new equivalent.
Ensure the referenced Provides element exists and the key matches exactly. Check for typos in the Key attribute value.
Do not set a log variable as a target for SetVariable. Log variables are read-only at install time. Use a different variable name.
Add the missing Provides element or correct the RequiresKey attribute. The Requires element must reference an existing Provides key.
Use a different value that is not reserved by the system. Check WiX documentation for reserved identifiers and values to avoid.
Check file permissions, ensure the source file exists and is not locked. Verify the destination path is accessible and has sufficient disk space.
Check file permissions and ensure the file is not in use by another process. Run as administrator if deleting from protected locations.
Verify source file exists, destination is writable, and both are on the same volume for atomic moves. Check for file locks.
Verify the file path is correct and the file exists. Check file permissions and ensure it's not locked by another process.
Either compress the payload or remove it from the container. Containers require compressed payloads. Set Compressed='yes' on the payload.
Add the package to the Chain element. All packages must be scheduled in the Chain to be installed.
Add the RollbackBoundary to the Chain element where you want it to apply. RollbackBoundary must be explicitly placed in the installation sequence.
Provide an implementation for the virtual symbol. Create a concrete element with the same identifier in your consuming project.
Ensure the virtual symbol exists in the referenced library. Check the symbol name for typos and verify the library is referenced correctly.
Set Win64='yes' on 64-bit components or ensure MSIX/64-bit architecture is specified. For x64 installs, all components in Program Files should be Win64.
Success - no action needed. The installation completed successfully.
Invalid data error. The MSI database or a parameter is corrupt. Rebuild the MSI package or check command line parameters.
Invalid parameter. Check command line syntax. Common issues: missing quotes around paths with spaces, invalid property names.
AppHelp block - installation blocked by Application Compatibility policy. Check Group Policy or remove conflicting compatibility shims.
Windows Installer service not accessible. Ensure the service is running: 'net start msiserver'. May require administrator privileges.
User cancelled installation. This is expected when user clicks Cancel. For silent installs, check if a conflicting dialog appeared.
Fatal installation error. Check the MSI log file (msiexec /l*v log.txt) for specific error. Common causes: missing prerequisites, file in use, permissions.
Installation suspended. Restart the computer and retry the installation.
Product not installed. The ProductCode doesn't match any installed product. Verify the correct product is targeted.
Feature not found. The requested feature ID doesn't exist in the product. Check ADDLOCAL or REMOVE property values.
Component not found. The ComponentId doesn't exist in the product. This may indicate a corrupt installation database.
Unknown property. The property name used doesn't exist. Check PUBLIC properties (all caps) are defined in Property table.
Invalid handle state. The installation handle is in an invalid state. Restart the installer service and retry.
Bad configuration data for this product. Reinstall or repair the product. May need to clean up registry entries.
Component qualifier not present. The assembly or component qualifier is missing from the registry.
Installation source not found. The original MSI or source files are unavailable. Point to correct source using SOURCELIST property.
Package version mismatch. The MSI package version doesn't match what's installed. Use the correct package version.
Product is already uninstalled. No action needed, or check if another version exists.
Another installation is in progress. Wait for the other installation to complete, or run 'msiexec /unregister' then 'msiexec /regserver'.
Cannot open MSI package. The file may be corrupt, missing, or blocked. Unblock downloaded files in file properties.
Invalid MSI package. The file is not a valid Windows Installer package. Re-download or rebuild the MSI.
UI failure in installer. There was a problem with the installer UI. Try silent install with /qn or check dialog resources.
Cannot open log file. Check permissions on log file location or choose different path. Ensure path exists.
Language not supported. The MSI doesn't support the system's language. Check ProductLanguage in Property table.
Transform application error. The MST transform file is invalid or doesn't apply to this MSI. Verify transform compatibility.
Installation forbidden by policy. Group Policy blocks this installation. Check Software Restriction Policies and DisableMSI settings.
Function failed during execution. Check MSI log for specific custom action or operation that failed.
Invalid script. A script-based custom action contains errors. Check VBScript or JavaScript custom actions.
Remote install not allowed. Remote installation from a share requires admin rights or different policy settings.
This MSI cannot be installed on this Windows version. Check the OS requirements in LaunchCondition table.
Failed to prepare rollback script. Disk space or permissions issue. Ensure temp folder has space and is writable.
Temp folder is full or inaccessible. Clear temp folder or set different temp location via TEMP environment variable.
Platform not supported. This MSI requires a different architecture (x86/x64/ARM). Use the correct package for your platform.
Component not found in feature. Internal MSI database error. Rebuild the MSI package.
Patch package cannot be opened. The MSP file is corrupt or requires a different base product. Verify patch applicability.
Cannot find patch target file. The base file for patching doesn't exist. Repair the base installation first.
Patch is inapplicable. This patch doesn't target the installed product version. Check ProductCode and UpgradeCode.
Another version of this product is installed. Uninstall the existing version first or use MajorUpgrade element.
Invalid command line argument. Check syntax of msiexec command, especially property assignments (PROPERTY=value).
SafeMode installation not possible. Cannot install in Windows Safe Mode. Boot normally and retry.
Reboot initiated. Installation succeeded but system restart was required. This is informational, not an error.
Patch cannot be applied. The installed product version doesn't match patch targets. Verify patch applies to installed version.
Patch superseded. A more recent patch has already been applied. No action needed.
Sequence information invalid. The patch sequencing information is corrupt or conflicts with other patches.
Patch removal disallowed. The patch was created with AllowRemoval='no'. Cannot uninstall this patch.
Invalid patch XML. The patch file contains malformed XML. Rebuild the patch package.
Patch not managed by WIM. Cannot patch a per-machine installation as per-user. Use correct installation context.
PatchCache policy prevents patching. Windows is configured to not cache patches. Update policy or use full file patches.
Product in advertised state. Cannot apply patch to advertised product. Complete the installation first.
Cannot patch per-machine MSI with per-user patch. Match the installation context (ALLUSERS setting).
Success, reboot required. Installation succeeded but a restart is needed to complete. Schedule a system restart.
